data.title: Linux: 'Git: pull' and 'Git: push' commands have no effect
data.body:
Testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19049

- Have a git repo with new commits and SCM Preview enabled
- Do 'Git: push' from the command palette
- Watching the Git output log, no new output appears, and the commits are not pushed

Same for git pull

data.title: Closing parenthesis dedents the line, but Format Document re-indents it
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insider
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a TypeScript file and type:
```ts
Math.max(
    1,
    2
```

2. Type `)`.
3. You will see:

```ts
Math.max(
    1,
2)
```

4. Use the "Format Document" command to bring back correct formatting (with an indent before `2)`).

data.title: SCM 'Sync' and 'publish' commands should be disabled when there is no remote
data.body:
Testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19049

In the Git viewlet, 'sync' and 'publish' under the '...' menu are disabled when the repo has no remotes. In the SCM viewlet, when I click 'sync', I see `fatal: No remote repository specified. Please, specify either a URL or a`. In the git output log, I see that there's a newline in the message at that point. Maybe when git output is shown directly as a notification, lines should be joined.

Terminal not updating view correctly. Backspace not removing all characters on screen

- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:49:23.350Z)

|Extension|Author|Version|

|code-gnu-global|austin|0.2.1|
|Arduino|moozzyk|0.0.4|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.9.2|
|cmake|twxs|0.0.15|
|cmake-tools|vector-of-bool|0.7.4|

User Settings:
"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Program Files\\Git\\bin\\bash.exe"

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7513089/22269046/c202371e-e257-11e6-9fa7-a91ce22ff113.png)

I have also seen other instances where other areas of the screen are not updated correctly, for example when using vim. I do not have a screenshot of this, though.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Terminal
2. Type "git status"
3. Press backspace rapidly until line is gone (leaves behind characters)

data.title: SCM doesn't persist diff view - inline vs side-by-side
data.body:
Testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19049

With SCM preview enabled,
- Make a change to a file
- Click the file in the SCM viewlet to open the diff view
- In the `...` editor dropdown, click "switch to inline view" (or side-by-side) to toggle the diff view style
- Close the diff editor
- Open the diff editor again
- See that the diff view style has reverted to the previous style, and now the option under the `...` menu doesn't match:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/323878/22268815/cde770f4-e23d-11e6-99b7-a34ec7dd7923.png)

data.title: Linux: "Open with Code" doesn't work when a Code window is already open
data.body:
Testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/18609

- On Ubuntu 14.04
- Open a Code window
- Open whatever you call the file explorer in Ubuntu
- Right click some file > Open With > Code Insiders
- A new Code window opens, but it has an untitled file, not the selected one

If I set `"window.openFilesInNewWindow": "off"`, it opens the actual file in the open Code window correctly.

data.title: No debugging without launch.json file when using debugger from extension
data.body:
Testing #18397 on Windows

- I have the Go extension installed and Go workspace opened with no launch.json file.
- There is a Go file opened in the active editor.
- I have added a breakpoint
- I click on the gear button in the debug side pane to create the launch.json file and there is a pop up asking me to choose the environment.
- I chose Go

Nothing happens. Debugger is not started.

In case you don't have Go and the Go extension installed, follow the below steps:
1. Install [Go](https://golang.org/doc/install#install)
2. Setup GOPATH
       1. Choose a folder where you will be having the Go projects
       2. Add env variable GOPATH with value as the above folder path
       3. Create 3 folders "src", "bin" and "pkg"
3. Run `go get github.com/golang/example/hello`
4. Install the Go extension by lukehoban and open the folder $GOPATH/src/GitHub.com/golang/example/hello in VS Code
5. Open the `hello.go` file. You will see "Analysis Tools Missing" in the status bar. Click on it to install the Go tools that the extension needs.

data.title: Why isn't security.workspacesTrustedToSpecifyExecutables a string[]?
data.body:
I don't see `false` being used much, why not make it a string[] to optimize the common case?

```js
"security.workspacesTrustedToSpecifyExecutables": [
	"$HOME/dev/Microsoft/vscode",
	"/home/daimms/dev/Microsoft/vscode"
]
```

vs

```js
"security.workspacesTrustedToSpecifyExecutables": {
	"$HOME/dev/Microsoft/vscode": true,
	"/home/daimms/dev/Microsoft/vscode": true
}
```

data.title: rename TypeImplementation Provider to Implementation Provider
Formatting json file removes new line at the end and save adds it back
data.body:
VS Code Insiders dated 2017/01/24

1. Open any json file with 1 or more new lines at the end
2. Format the file => the new lines in the end get removed
3. Save the file => one new line in the end gets added.

Save does not add that new line in VS Code 1.8.1

data.title: Why show total # of settings or # of settings matched at all?
data.body:

What does the user gain by knowing that there are 448 settings?

While searching, we match both on LHS and the RHS. The settings matched number I believe is only from LHS. Isnt that misleading?

data.title: Task runner writes to output and terminal

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.title: Node related configuration snippets showing up in non Node environment
data.body:
Testing #19039

- I have the Go extension installed and Go workspace opened with no launch.json file.
- There is a Go file opened in the active editor.
- I click on the "Add Configuration" option in the debug drop down and there is a pop up asking me to choose the environment.
- I choose Go
- The default launch.json is created by the Go extension.
- The snippets for adding new configuration have nothing to do with Go. Why are they even showing up?

In case you don't have Go and the Go extension installed, follow the below steps:
1. Install [Go](https://golang.org/doc/install#install)
2. Setup GOPATH
       1. Choose a folder where you will be having the Go projects
       2. Add env variable GOPATH with value as the above folder path
       3. Create 3 folders "src", "bin" and "pkg"
3. Run `go get github.com/golang/example/hello`
4. Install the Go extension by lukehoban and open the folder $GOPATH/src/GitHub.com/golang/example/hello in VS Code
5. Open the `hello.go` file. You will see "Analysis Tools Missing" in the status bar. Click on it to install the Go tools that the extension needs.

In that case, we should add the dots to the button as well?

data.title: "This workspace specifies executables" message box should remember "Do Not Trust Workspace" selection
data.body:
It would be good if this was remembered in local storage.

Steps to reproduce:

1. Open untrusted workspace
2. Press do not trust workspace
3. Reload window, you're presented with the message box again.

data.title: Improve 'Press any key to close the terminal'
data.body:
Testing #19057

- When a task terminates, the terminal says:
'Press any key to close the terminal' 

Maybe better 'Press any key to close'.
It just closes the terminal instance. The terminal stays open if there are other instances.

data.title: [WelcomeUX] Whitelist workspace.welcome.enabled
Popup to chose environment shouldnt show up when file type is supported by debugger from an extension
data.body:
Testing #18397 on Windows

- I have the Go extension installed and Go workspace opened with no launch.json file.
- There is a Go file opened in the active editor.
- I click on the gear button in the debug side pane to create the launch.json file and there is a pop up asking me to choose the environment.

According to the test plan, the Go environment should have been automatically chosen:

> Once you want to generate the launch.json it will only ask to choose the environment if the currently open file type is not supported by any debugger. 

In case you don't have Go and the Go extension installed, follow the below steps:
1. Install [Go](https://golang.org/doc/install#install)
2. Setup GOPATH
       1. Choose a folder where you will be having the Go projects
       2. Add env variable GOPATH with value as the above folder path
       3. Create 3 folders "src", "bin" and "pkg"
3. Run `go get github.com/golang/example/hello`
4. Install the Go extension by lukehoban and open the folder $GOPATH/src/GitHub.com/golang/example/hello in VS Code
5. Open the `hello.go` file. You will see "Analysis Tools Missing" in the status bar. Click on it to install the Go tools that the extension needs.

data.title: Multiple debugging sessions when play button is hit multiple times while debugging single file without launch.json
data.body:
Testing #18397 on Windows

- Open a single js file in VS Code Insiders (no breakpoints)
- Open the Debug Side Pane
- Click the Play button to start debugging
- Click again
- Now there are 2 Launch processes running. As a user, I am not sure why. The first one should have closed. Or the second should be a no-op
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16890566/22263120/3d62bed6-e228-11e6-924c-4e2e43fa792b.png)
- Click on the red stop button. Now I see this
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16890566/22263171/5e87113e-e228-11e6-8437-cb2fb9c37a23.png)
The drop down has just 1 option.
Why is the drop down even here?
- Click on the red stop button a second time. All debugging is stopped.

If I tried the same in a workspace with a launch.json,
- Clicking on the Play button the second time is a no-op
- Clicking on the Red stop button stops the debugging. No need to click twice
- The drop down is in the side pane not in the floating debug bar
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16890566/22263339/f3703b2c-e228-11e6-9b59-3afe1233556c.png)
